At the time of writing, PhilPeriodicals has 5 exhibits and 2 collections.

Check out the slides above to see samples from the exhibit on Minorities in the Philippines, which focuses on how cultural minorities were represented in media from the Spanish era to two decades after the end of World War II. Specifically, the exhibit focuses on the Muslim and Chinese minorities in the country, referred to as Moros and Sangley respectively.

The cultural diversity present posed a challenge to colonial goals of ‘civilising’ and ‘Christianising’ the local population.

"Revista de la decena" above features a dialogue between two people: a Spaniard and a Filipino of lower status, who addresses the Spaniard as señor. They talk casually about the state of affairs in the Philippines. At a given moment, the dialogue addresses a clash between Moros and Spanish troops, and one of the speakers expresses that it would be better to wipe out the Moros for their “not being Christian, not paying taxes, and not being good for anything”, to which the other agrees. The piece spearheaded several numbers as an editorial. This was published in the satiric newspaper La Puya, which intended to feature Philippine current affairs with sarcasm, like satiric newspapers in Spain. According to Wenceslao Retana, it was founded in 1892 by the Spaniard Adolfo Puya y Ruíz. Full details and metadata can be found on PhilPeriodicals.

The article fictionalizes clashes between the army and Moro rebels, characterized as the villains. A portrait of “Captain Leon Angeles” is captioned as “conquers moro outlaws”. The Moros are described as ringing agongs, a gong-like musical instrument, wearing barongs, and being armed with spears, contrasting the army who are armed with modern weaponry. Full details and metadata on PhilPeriodicals.

This illustration, by V. Manansala, is included in the short story "Mr. Flores Problem", by Purificación Dagdag, in which teacher Flores, the principal teacher stops the violent outburst of a Moro named Sadani, who was wielding a bloodied kris. Despite his fury, Sadani calms down after being confronted by someone he respected. Full details and metadata on PhilPeriodicals.
